noun.description: A particular position or point in space.
examples: the monastery was a peaceful place
that street was no place for a lady
there were still some remote places in the world

noun.description: A portion of space available or designated for or being used by someone.
examples: they hurried to their places at the table
he was watching from his place across the room

noun.description: A position in a sequence or series, typically one ordered on the basis of merit.
(in place names) a square or a short street.
examples: our new restaurant is in Hilliard Place
a newspaper had been placed beside my plate

verb.description: Find a home or employment for.
examples: the children were placed with foster parents
the agency had placed 3,000 people in full-time jobs

verb.description: Identify or classify as being of a specified type or as holding a specified position in a sequence or hierarchy.
examples: a survey placed the company 13th for achievement

phrases: we've been all over the place looking for you
the government is all over the place on this
The present school-house will soon give place to a more extensive and pretentious one, to be built on a more elevated situation.

Plows had to give place to politics for the next four years, so it was not until the end of 1793, when he was on the brink of retirement from George Washington's cabinet, that Jefferson took measures to test his theory.
By the 1930s, however, these approaches were already giving place to a very different estimate of the play's artistic success.
origin: Middle English: from Old French, from an alteration of Latin platea open space, from Greek plateia (hodos) broad (way).
